Package infodynamics.measures.continuous

Interface PredictiveInfoCalculator

  • All Superinterfaces:
    EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer, InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    PredictiveInfoCalculatorGaussian, PredictiveInfoCalculatorKernel, PredictiveInfoCalculatorKraskov, PredictiveInfoCalculatorViaMutualInfo
    public interface PredictiveInfoCalculator
extends InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous, EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
    Interface for implementations of Predictive Information / Excess Entropy estimators on continuous univariate data (ie double[] arrays).

    See definition of Predictive Information (PI) / Excess Entropy in the citations below. Basically, PI is the mutual information between the past state of a time-series process X and its future state. The past state at time n is represented by an embedding vector of k values from X_n backwards, each separated by \tau steps, giving X^k_n = [ X_{n-(k-1)\tau}, ... , X_{n-\tau}, X_n]. The future state from time n+1 is represented by an embedding vector of k values from X_{n+1} forwards, each separated by \tau steps, giving X^{k+}_{n+1} = [ X_{n+1}, X_{n+1+\tau}, ... , X_{n+1+(k-1)\tau}]. We call k the embedding dimension, and \tau the embedding delay. PI is then the mutual information between X^k_n and X^{k+}_{n+1}.

    Usage of the child classes implementing this interface is intended to follow this paradigm:

    1. Construct the calculator;
    2. Set properties using setProperty(String, String);
    3. Initialise the calculator using InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous.initialise() or initialise(int) or initialise(int, int);
    4. Provide the observations/samples for the calculator to set up the PDFs, using:
      • setObservations(double[]) or setObservations(double[], boolean[]) for calculations based on single time-series, OR
      • The following sequence:
        1. startAddObservations(), then
        2. One or more calls to addObservations(double[]) or addObservations(double[], int, int), then
        3. finaliseAddObservations();
    5. Compute the required quantities, being one or more of:
      • the average PI: InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous.computeAverageLocalOfObservations();
      • the local PI values for these samples: computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
      • local PI values for a specific set of samples: computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[])
      • the distribution of PI values under the null hypothesis of no relationship between past sequences in the series and the next sequence: EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer.computeSignificance(int) or EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer.computeSignificance(int[][]).
    6. Return to step 2 or 3 to re-use the calculator on a new data set.

    References:

    • Bialek, W., Nemenman, I., and Tishby, N., "Complexity through nonextensivity", Physica A, 302, 89-99. (2001).
    • J. P. Crutchfield, D. P. Feldman, "Regularities Unseen, Randomness Observed: Levels of Entropy Convergence", Chaos, Vol. 13, No. 1. (2003), pp. 25-54.
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field Description
      static java.lang.String K_EMBEDDING_PROP_NAME
      Property name for embedding length k of the past and future vectors (1 by default).
      static java.lang.String K_PROP_NAME
      Alternative property name for embedding length k of the past and future vectors (1 by default); a second option, in order to provide compatibility with ActiveInfoStorageCalculator.K_PROP_NAME
      static java.lang.String TAU_PROP_NAME
      Property name for embedding delay \tau of the vectors (1 by default).

      • K_EMBEDDING_PROP_NAME

        Property name for embedding length k of the past and future vectors (1 by default).
        See Also:

      • K_PROP_NAME

        static final java.lang.String K_PROP_NAME
        Alternative property name for embedding length k of the past and future vectors (1 by default); a second option, in order to provide compatibility with ActiveInfoStorageCalculator.K_PROP_NAME
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • TAU_PROP_NAME

        static final java.lang.String TAU_PROP_NAME
        Property name for embedding delay \tau of the vectors (1 by default). The delay exists between points in the k-vectors but there is always only one time step between the past k-vector and the next k-vector.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • setProperty

        void setProperty​(java.lang.String propertyName,
                 java.lang.String propertyValue)
          throws java.lang.Exception
        Set properties for the underlying calculator implementation. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        Property names defined at the interface level, and what their values should represent, include:

        • K_PROP_NAME or #K__EMBEDDING_PROP_NAME -- embedding length k of the past and future vectors
        • TAU_PROP_NAME -- embedding delay between each of the k points in the vectors.

        Unknown property values are ignored.

        Note that implementing classes may defined additional properties.

        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        propertyValue - value of the property
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for invalid property values

      • setObservations

        void setObservations​(double[] observations)
              throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets a single time-series from which to compute the PDF for the PI. Cannot be called in conjunction with other methods for setting/adding observations.
        Parameters:
        observations - time-series array of (univariate) samples, where the array index is time.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • startAddObservations

        void startAddObservations()
        Signal that we will add in the samples for computing the PDF from several disjoint time-series or trials via calls to addObservations(double[]) etc.

      • addObservations

        void addObservations​(double[] observations)
              throws java.lang.Exception
        Add more time-series for the computation of the PDF. The array observations must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called.
        Parameters:
        observations - time-series array of (univariate) samples, where the array index is time.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • addObservations

        void addObservations​(double[] observations,
                     int startTime,
                     int numTimeSteps)
              throws java.lang.Exception
        Add more time-series for the computation of the PDF, using only a sub-series of observations. The array observations must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called.
        Parameters:
        observations - time-series array of (univariate) samples, where the array index is time.
        startTime - first time index to extract samples from
        numTimeSteps - number of time steps to extract starting from startTime
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • finaliseAddObservations

        void finaliseAddObservations()
                      throws java.lang.Exception
        Signal that the observations are now all added, PDFs can now be constructed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • setObservations

        void setObservations​(double[] observations,
                     boolean[] valid)
              throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets a single time-series from which to compute the PDF for the AIS, subject to the validity of each sample in that series. Cannot be called in conjunction with other methods for setting/adding observations.
        Parameters:
        observations - time-series array of (univariate) samples, where the array index is time.
        valid - a time series (with indices the same as observations) indicating whether the entry in observations at that index is valid; we only take vectors as samples to add to the observation set where all points in the time series (even between points in the embedded k-vector with embedding delays) are valid.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

        double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the local PI values for each of the previously-supplied samples.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations.

        If the samples were supplied via a single call such as setObservations(double[]), then the return value is a single time-series of local PI values corresponding to these samples (with the first, and last, (k-1)*tau + 1 values set to 0 since PI is undefined there).

        Otherwise where disjoint time-series observations were supplied using several calls such as addObservations(double[]) then the local values for each disjoint observation set will be appended here to create a single "time-series" return array (without any (k-1)*tau + 1 leading or lagging 0 values).

        Returns:
        the "time-series" of local AIS values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

        double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations​(double[] newObservations)
                                        throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the local PI values for each of the supplied samples in newObservations.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations, but not those in newObservations (unless they were some of the previously supplied samples).

        Parameters:
        newObservations - time-series for which to compute local PI values
        Returns:
        time-series of local PI values corresponding to newObservations (the first, and last, (k-1)*tau + 1 values are set to 0 since PI is undefined there)
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for an invalid input array, e.g. of length less than 2*k
